definitions.definition: to walk slowly around or to a place, often without any particular sense of purpose or direction

examples.text: She wandered aimlessly around the streets.
We wandered back towards the car.
The child was found wandering the streets alone.
Don't go wandering all over the house!
He just wandered in one day and asked for a job.
He wandered into a bar and ordered a drink.
One day she wandered further afield.
Simply wandering is a pleasure in itself.
The cattle are allowed to wander freely.
They found him wandering around aimlessly.
Visitors are free to wander through the gardens and woods.
Cattle and sheep wander freely on the hilltops.
During the day I would wander the streets, asking passers-by for a few cents.
He was found wandering in the road late one night.
She had spent her life wandering from place to place.
They spent a couple of hours wandering through the markets.

definitions.definition: to move away from the place where you ought to be or the people you are with

examples.text: The child wandered off and got lost.
How could you let him wander off like that?
They had wandered from the path into the woods.

definitions.definition: to stop being directed on something and to move without much control to other ideas, subjects, etc.
definitions.sensetop: wander away, back, to, etc. something

examples.text: It's easy to be distracted and **let your attention wander**.
Try not to **let your mind wander**.
Her thoughts wandered back to her youth.
examples.contextForm: wander away, back, to, etc. something

examples.text: Don’t wander off the subject—keep to the point.
Lisa let her mind wander a little.
His attention was beginning to wander.
My thoughts wandered from the exam questions to my interview the next day.

definitions.definition: to move slowly from looking at one thing to looking at another thing or in other directions

examples.text: She **let her gaze wander**.
His eyes wandered towards the photographs on the wall.

definitions.definition: to go in a curve instead of following a straight course

examples.text: The road wanders along through the hills.

wordOrigin: Old English wandrian, of West Germanic origin; related to wend and wind2.
